articles.headline: The Lumia 1020, a Great Camera Grafted to an Oddball Phone
articles.snippet: Big, but not unwieldy, Nokia’s Lumia 1020 cellphone takes excellent photos, and is essentially a decent camera grafted onto a phone. But you’ll have to make peace with its apps and its Windows operating system.
articles.abstract: Big, but not unwieldy, Nokia’s Lumia 1020 cellphone takes excellent photos, and is essentially a decent camera grafted onto a phone. But you’ll have to make peace with its apps and its Windows operating system.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, every decent photo from a cellphone has earned the same faint praise: “That’s a great picture! You know, for a cellphone.”

articles.headline: Licensing Plan Gives Fresh Plays to Beatles
articles.snippet: A new business venture, which secured the rights to six Beatles songs, has a licensing strategy that is pushing the music onto television and the movies.
articles.abstract: A new business venture, which secured the rights to six Beatles songs, has a licensing strategy that is pushing the music onto television and the movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Paul McCartney closed the Grammy Awards last year with an all-star Beatles medley, Owen Husney, a veteran music executive, read Twitter in horror. In one message after another, young people asked a question that could give a baby boomer a heart attack: “Who is Paul McCartney?!”

articles.headline: The Internet’s Verbal Contrarian
articles.snippet: The writer Evgeny Morozov has quickly become the most prominent critic of the utopian promises coming from Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: The writer Evgeny Morozov has quickly become the most prominent critic of the utopian promises coming from Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: For every revolution, there is a counterrevolutionary. And so the digital one has brought us Evgeny Morozov.

articles.headline: Old Economies Rise as Growing Markets Begin to Falter
articles.snippet: Economies in Japan and the United States are growing and Europe appears to be easing away from a recession just as growth is slowing in Brazil, Russia, India and China.
articles.abstract: Economies in Japan and the United States are growing and Europe appears to be easing away from a recession just as growth is slowing in Brazil, Russia, India and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: The balance of world economic growth is tipping in another direction. Just as economists have begun lowering their forecasts for China and many other developing economies, the American economy is bouncing back. Japan appears to have turned a corner and is ending almost two decades of grinding deflation. Economic data out of Europe on Wednesday provided the first solid indication that many countries in the euro zone may be escaping the clutches of recession.

articles.headline: Fierce and Swift Raids on Islamists Bring Sirens, Gunfire, Then Screams
articles.snippet: The military-backed government in Egypt had hinted at a milder clearing operation that would last days. But when it came, protesters appeared stunned by its fury.
articles.abstract: The military-backed government in Egypt had hinted at a milder clearing operation that would last days. But when it came, protesters appeared stunned by its fury.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Hayam Hussein had gone to sleep, with her infant daughter by her side, after early-morning prayers. One moment, silence. Then, the sound of war.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Alters View of Mergers by Airlines
articles.snippet: Regulators and industry officials continue to debate the merits of a possible merger between American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.abstract: Regulators and industry officials continue to debate the merits of a possible merger between American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after the Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, regulators and industry officials continued to wrestle with a central question: What is the best way to protect consumers?
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Intermittent Nature of Green Power Is Challenge for Utilities
articles.snippet: When a Vermont wind farm was required to cut back generation, the episode prompted a larger debate about the alternative energy’s place in the nation’s power supply.
articles.abstract: When a Vermont wind farm was required to cut back generation, the episode prompted a larger debate about the alternative energy’s place in the nation’s power supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 21 turbines at the Kingdom Community Wind farm in Vermont soar above Lowell Mountain, a testament in steel and fiberglass to the state’s growing use of green energy.

articles.headline: Islamists Debate Their Next Move in Tense Cairo
articles.snippet: A quiet settled over Egypt’s capital the day after a crackdown that killed over 600, as the city braced for new protests by the supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.abstract: A quiet settled over Egypt’s capital the day after a crackdown that killed over 600, as the city braced for new protests by the supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Gathering Thursday morning around a mosque used as a morgue for hundreds killed the day before, many Islamists waited confidently for a surge of sympathetic support from the broader public. But it failed to materialize.

articles.headline: His Options Few, Obama Rebukes Egypt’s Leaders
articles.snippet: President Obama warned of taking future steps against Egypt but made no mention of cutting off $1.5 billion in military and economic aid to the country.
articles.abstract: President Obama warned of taking future steps against Egypt but made no mention of cutting off $1.5 billion in military and economic aid to the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — President Obama announced Thursday that the United States had canceled longstanding joint military exercises with the Egyptian Army set for next month, using one of his few obvious forms of leverage to rebuke Egypt’s military-backed government for its brutal crackdown on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Grim Picture of Recovery in Forecasts by Retailers
articles.snippet: Despite signs of a reviving economy, several big retail chains said consumers were still limiting their spending to the essentials.
articles.abstract: Despite signs of a reviving economy, several big retail chains said consumers were still limiting their spending to the essentials.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lot of Americans are still spending their money only on socks and other essentials, highlighting the disparity between younger and poorer consumers and those who are benefiting from the economic recovery.
